ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: You cannot graduate from FES without learning climate policy from Bob Sussman. He offers an in-depth, expertly curated climate policy for dummies. I knew nothing when we started and now I am obsessed with climate related policy, talking about it with everyone i know and scanning new articles constantly.
Q12: I think learning about all of the different policies in place or that may be in place to help combat climate change is very important for anyone in this program.
Workload was more in-line with a 3-credit class.

for question 4, the pace wasn't too fast, I indicated my answer simply because it is a fast paced class but necessarily so in order to cover all the material in the depth we were able to--I wouldn't change this

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I really liked our group discussions.
A systematic introduction to US climate policies and great opportunity to discuss the latest changes.

Loved learning from him. He gave us only the best/most important articles to read...even if some of those were the Clean Power Plan, he would point us to the best sections to read. He really took good care of us. His powerpoints had all of the most vital information. I feel like I REALLY REALLY Learned from this course.
The professor has real world experience and is very knowledgeable about the subjects. He is also very responsive to students and helpful.
Breadth of topics covered, knowledge of instructor, great guest lectures.

This was truly the most impactful course I have taken. Professor Sussman put so much care and time into a class--the slides are amazingly comprehensive and his readings were always the most up to date best sources on the subjects one could find making every bit of the course and what we took away valuable. If things in the media changed, he would always come to class ready to present and discuss them.
The quality of readings and lecture slides.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think the final project lost its relevance a bit with the election. In future years, I think it's important to focus less on this final project.
Workload is a bit more than an usual course of 2 credits.

This course should be a 3 credit course for the amount of work it had. To be a two credit course, there should not be a presentation and big final paper and big midterm. Also, there must be another way to present the policies, because with the power point it was very very dry and dull, and these are interesting things! Is there a way to put less so we can do more?? Feel like I don't remember 80% of what was presented, and we only grazed the surface.

If anything I would say this course would benefit from a follow up class in the spring but I have no criticism for the class itself--it was one of the best taught and well organized courses I have taken (especially for a seminar!)
Reading materials were often too much (500+ pages a week). Some weeks they were just right (100 is fine).

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I took this class as an undergraduate EVST major and it directly correlates with what I hope to concentrate in so the class was extremely helpful in giving me greater breadth and depth in environmental and energy studies.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about how to reduce our emissions to meet our international COP21 commitments.
Want to get a general idea of US climate policies.
To fill my knowledge gap!
Wanted to take a policy course
Out of interest and passion for the topics it covered.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I think I learned a lot--and realized this isn't an easy feat like some environmentalists may state.
This course exceeded my expectations!
Yes, I enjoyed it a lot.
Surpassed
Yes
yes and far surpassed them.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I'm not a fan of group final projects, but we did the best we could.
Group assignment was great. We had to present a plan to reach the COP21 goal of U.S. GHG reductions.
Really fun to work on a team to craft new climate policies and advice for the incomign admin.
We weren't really sure how to generate the MMT numbers because Rhodium used an "algorithm" that we wouldn't have understood or been able to mimic.
Group paper is not an effective use of time and did not provide a value-add. It would have been better to do a second individual paper.

The advantages were the opportunity to learn from my peers and their vast experiences. I loved talking through the topics and hearing their differing viewpoints. Our group did a good job of sticking together in many ways on the big picture and trying to keep everyone on the same page. the one disadvantage of this was that we didn't always have a clear line of say, a sector, that each person was in charge of which at first seemed like a good idea but in the end sort of led to a lack of accountability and writing a lot of the sections fell on just a few of us--but i'm still glad we didn't split it up into sectors in the beginning since I wouldn't have had the chance to get as great of a big picture.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's good, just take it.
Do as much of the readings as possible and participate in discussion!

This is an amazing amazing class--it gives the most comprehensive and succinct break down of US climate policy you will find. Professor Sussman is brilliant, extremely caring and dedicated to his work--I would take any class he teaches. He will put a ton of time into the course--the slides are amazingly comprehensive and his readings were always the most up to date best sources on the subjects one could find making every bit of the course and what we took away valuable.
